	Safe Operating Limits:  A process variable that, at some measurable level, may lead to reaching/exceeding a design limit and a catastrophic event.  Operating systems and/or sub-systems are evaluated to identify credible scenarios that may warrant establishing a safe operating limit on a process variable due to the potential consequences.
	Safe Upper and/or Lower Limit:  The boundaries of the design operating envelope (MAWP, MAWT, composition) of a specific piece of equipment, i.e. design basis/boundaries.  It is the limit above (or below) which it is considered unknown or unsafe to operate.
	Self-Audit:  The structured process, undertaken by personnel normally working within the audited part of the organization, of collecting information to determine the efficiency, effectiveness and reliability of an EHS management system or program and evaluating how effectively EHS risks are being managed.
	Temporary Change:  A change that is needed for only a limited period of time to maintain system operation; one that has an expiration date or removal date.
	Trade Secret:  Any confidential formula, pattern, process, device, information, or compilation of information that is used in an employer's business and that gives the employer an opportunity to obtain an advantage over competitors who do not know or use it [OSHA 1910.119].  It may be a formula for a chemical compound, a process of manufacturing, treating, or preserving materials, a pattern for a machine or other device, or a list of customers [29 CFR 1910.1200, App. D]. 
	Utility:  Steam, vacuum, water, gases, solvents, HVAC, waste and power provided for BASF buildings and processes.
	Visitor:  Any person, whether employed by BASF or not, who visits a BASF facility but does not work there regularly.
	Waste:  Unwanted or surplus materials left over from any process or ac

design and development of operating procedures.  There are several industry accepted methods for conducting a PHA such as Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), What-If/Checklist, Fault Tree Analysis, and Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA). 
	Process Safety Information (PSI):  A compilation of chemical hazard, technology, and equipment documentation needed to manage process safety.  It may include documentation such as material hazards, process and equipment design basis, and other basic process technology documentation. 
	Production:  Activities involved in the preparation of a product from raw/intermediate material feeds through to processing.
	PSM Compliance Audit:  A comprehensive audit of a facility's PSM Program that must be conducted at least once every three years to be compliant with OSHA Process Safety Management 29 CFR 1910.119 in order to determine the effectiveness of the program.
	Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practice (RAGAGEP):  Engineering, operation, or maintenance activities based on established codes, standards, published technical reports or recommended practices (RP) or a similar document.
	Remediation:  The act of restoring the surface and/or subsurface of all or a portion of a site to a condition that is appropriate for subsequent industrial or public use. 
	Repair:  See Corrective Maintenance.
	Replacement-In-Kind (RIK):  Replacement of an item with a direct substitute that meets the original design specification and does not alter the process conditions.  Also called like-for-like.
	Revalidation PHA:  A PHA conducted typically every 5 years to review and update the existing PHA to ensure that it is up-to-date and meets current requirements.
	Risk:  The perceived outcome of an event and can be measured in terms of severity of consequence and likelihood of occurrence.
	Risk Assessment (Safety):  A systematic examination of activities or processes to identify the probability of EHS adverse events,

Oxygen-enriched Atmosphere:  An atmosphere that contains more than 23.5% oxygen by volume.
	PMU:  Process, Maintenance, & Utility.
	Portable Tank:  A closed container having a liquid capacity over 60 U.S. gallons and not intended for fixed installation.
	Predictive Maintenance:  An equipment maintenance strategy based on measuring the condition of equipment in order to assess when it may fail, and then taking appropriate action to avoid the consequences of that failure.
	Pre-Start Up Safety Review (PSSR):  A formal documented review designed to ensure that EHS issues have been adequately addressed for new and modified BASF processes and equipment.  The review provides assurance of safe operation and covers technical and management issues such as equipment operability and construction specifications, training, operating / emergency procedures and changes to procedures.
	Preventive Maintenance:  An equipment maintenance strategy based upon the systematic inspection, detection and correction of incipient failures either before they occur or before they develop into major defects.  Includes tests, measurements, adjustments, lubrication and parts replacement performed specifically to prevent failures from occurring. 
	Procedure:  A written, formally approved document that specifies the actions required to accomplish an intended task and the responsibilities for completing those actions, together with any record sheets or checklists that may be appropriate to ensure that those actions are carried out in a consistent manner and are recorded. 
	Process:  Any chemical, biological or other method used to synthesize, produce or develop a chemical entity, intermediate or final product in manufacturing or development. 
	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):  A formal documented evaluation of the risks associated with any process.  It begins at the start of the design phase of a process to ensure that all hazardous operations are adequately considered in the engineering

n-toxic and non-flammable materials (e.g. steam, hot condensate, nitrogen, compressed CO2 or compressed air).
	Limiting Oxidant Concentration:  Minimum volume concentration of oxidant required to support combustion.
	Manufacturing:  Any or all operations involved in preparing, controlling and supplying a product from the receipt, acceptance and dispensing of all starting materials, raw materials, excipients or packaging components, through processing and packing, including in-process controls, testing and release activities, and dispatching from site.
	Material:  All-encompassing term for any substance, regardless of physical form.
	Mechanical Integrity (MI):  A management system for ensuring the ongoing durability and functionality of equipment.
	Mechanical Integrity Quality Assurance:  Activities to ensure that equipment is designed and installed appropriately and to ensure that the design intent is not compromised throughout the equipment's entire life cycle.  This also includes systems and activities to assure that in-scope maintenance materials, spare parts and equipment are suitable for the process application for which they will be used.
	Mitigate:  To manage an impact or risk in a way that makes it less serious, or to introduce a positive impact designed to balance out a negative impact.
	Maximum Intended Inventory:  is the total quantity of a highly hazardous chemical that may be present.  This includes piping, vessels, tanks, etc.
	Nondestructive Testing/Examination (NDT/NDE):  Evaluation of equipment with the intention of measuring an equipment parameter without damaging or destroying the equipment item, e.g., ultrasonic pipe or vessel thickness measurement.
	Oxidizing:  Substances or wastes which, while in themselves not necessarily combustible, may, generally (by yielding oxygen) cause, or contribute to, the combustion of other materials. 
	Oxygen-deficient Atmosphere:  An atmosphere that contains less than 19.5% oxygen by volume.

	Inerting:  The displacement of the atmosphere in a confined space by a non-combustible gas (such as nitrogen) to such an extent that the resulting atmosphere is non-combustible.
	Inherently Safe Design:  A system, process, or operation so designed that it remains in a non-hazardous state after the occurrence of deviations from normal operating conditions.
	Inspection:  Routine examination of work areas, equipment, tasks or materials to determine whether they conform to required criteria with regard to EHS impacts and performance.  Where non-conformances are identified, investigations or corrective action is initiated.
	ITPM Program:  A management system that develops, maintains, monitors, and manages Inspection, Testing, and Preventive Maintenance activities to maintain mechanical integrity of the equipment. 
	Lower Explosive Limit (LEL):  The minimum concentration of gas or vapor in the air (normally measured by volume) for which flame propagation can occur after ignition.
	Lower Flammability Limit (LFL):  An alternative term for LEL.
	Line Breaking:  The intentional opening of a pipe, line, or duct that has been carrying flammable, corrosive, or toxic material, an inert gas or any fluid at a volume, pressure, or temperature capable of causing injury.
	Lock-out / Tag-out (LOTO):  A method of ensuring that equipment remains isolated from all sources of energy while it is being maintained, modified or repaired and thereby preventing personnel injury either by the energy sources themselves or as a result of inadvertent operation of the equipment.  Its underlying principle is that the isolation is secured with a padlock.  Each person working on the equipment essentially controls access to the lock keys until the work is complete.
	Loss of Primary Containment (LOPC):  An unplanned or uncontrolled release of any material from primary containment, including no

int below 100 °F. (37.8 °C.), except any mixture having components with flashpoints of 100 °F. (37.8 °C.) or higher, the total of which make up 99 percent or more of the total volume of the mixture.
	Flash Point:  The minimum temperature at which a liquid gives off vapor within a test vessel in sufficient concentration to form an ignitable mixture with air near the surface of the liquid.  The flash point is normally an indication of susceptibility to ignition.
	Hazard:  Something that has the potential to cause loss, injury or illness, damage to equipment, facilities, the environment or the business.  The inherently dangerous properties of materials or substances.
See also 'Risk'
	Hazardous Atmosphere:  An atmosphere that may expose employees to the risk of death, incapacitation, impairment of ability to rescue themselves (that is, escape unaided from a confined space), injury or acute illness from one or more of the following causes:
- flammable gas, vapor or mist in excess of 10% of its Lower Explosive Limit (LEL) or Lower Flammable Limit (LFL);
- airborne combustible dust at a concentration that meets or exceeds its LEL or LFL;
- atmospheric oxygen concentration below 19.5% or above 23.5%;
- atmospheric concentration of any substance exceeding the occupational exposure limit;
- any other atmospheric condition that is IDLH.
	Highly Hazardous Chemical:  is a substance possessing toxic, reactive, flammable, or explosive properties as specified by OSHA 1910.119 paragraph (a)(1).
	Hot Work:  Any temporary or permanent operation involving open flames or producing heat and/or sparks. This includes but is not limited to: brazing, cutting, grinding, soldering, torch applied roofing and welding.
	Hot Work Permit:  The written authorization to perform hot work (e.g., welding, cutting, burning, angle grinding, soldering, heating and riveting).
	Incident (safety):  An unplanned deviation from normal operating practice that either resulted in harm, such as

used by BASF.
	Dangerous Goods: Chemical, biological and radioactive substances and articles capable of posing significant risk to health, safety, property and environment, when transported. 
	Documentation: Any written record of standards, procedures, instructions, actions, decisions, non-compliances, checks and inspections. Documentation may be in the form of minutes, memos, faxes, letters, file notes, completed check-sheets, batch records, emails and database entries.
	EHS-Critical Equipment / Spares: Equipment that, if it were to fail, would reduce the control of EHS risks, compliance with the Global EHS Standards and compliance with EHS regulatory requirements. Spares for such equipment.
	Emergency:  Abnormal situations such as releases of flammable, explosive, toxic or corrosive materials, fire or explosions, medical need etc. 
	Emergency Change:  A change that requires immediate action to avoid injury to plant personnel, damage to equipment or facilities, adverse impact on the environment or community, or severe economic penalty.
	Employee:  Person who is on the BASF payroll and entitled to benefits. The individual may be either full- time or part- time. 
	Engineering Control Measure:  Measure which controls the working environment in a manner that limits the exposure of individuals to a particular hazard without the use of personal protective equipment or administrative controls.  Examples include machine enclosures, local exhaust ventilation, laboratory fume hoods, etc..
	Equipment Deficiency:  A condition in equipment containing highly hazardous chemicals that does not meet the acceptance criteria described in the Process Safety Information / ITPM plan and requires equipment to be removed from service before further use or establish interim means to assure safe operation until a timely resolution can be obtained.
	Facility:  Premises, equipment and utilities used or owned by BASF Seneca.
	Flammable (liquid):  Any liquid having a flashpo

erials that could cause illness or injury, or harm to the environment, regardless of physical form
	Combustible Liquid: Any liquid having a flashpoint at or above 100 °F. (37.8 °C.).
	Combustible Solid: Any material which may be ignited under the circumstances of use and create a fire or explosion.
	Commissioning: A documented process that provides assurance that an analytical method, control method, system, computer, production process or equipment, consistently and reproducibly perform in a way that conforms to a predetermined specification.
	Computerized Maintenance Management System (CMMS): Software for planning, scheduling and documenting maintenance activities.  A typical CMMS includes work order generation, work instructions, parts and labor expenditure tracking, parts inventories and equipment histories.
	Containment, Primary: A tank, vessel, pipe, truck, rail car or equipment intended to serve as the primary container or used for processing or transfer of material.
	Containment, Secondary: Exists to contain or control a release from primary containment.  Secondary containment systems include, but are not limited to tank dikes, curbing around process equipment, drainage collection systems, the outer wall of double walled tanks, etc.
	Contamination: Introduction into water, air or soil of; physical, chemical, biological, or radiological substances in a concentration that makes the medium unfit for its next intended use. 
	Corrective Maintenance, (repairs):  Activities which occur to return a failed piece of equipment, system or plant back to its original, healthy state.  Corrective maintenance/repair work does not involve changes or modifications; it is a return to a known functional state with the same form, fit and function as existed prior to the failure condition.

6.1.14	Emergency Response
6.1.14.1	BASF Seneca has established and implemented an emergency action plan according to OSHA regulations.  Refer to the Seneca Integrated Contingency Plan procedure EHS 00003 located in CompliantPro for information regarding the response to emergencies.  Seneca also has an Emergency Alarm Response Procedure 05001 to address initial response to site emergency alarms.  Four areas within the site have personnel who remain in the area, if safe to do so, in order to secure the processes/shutdown equipment.  These areas are PPD, EAF, Utilities, and Zeolites and each has an area specific Emergency Response Procedure to direct the actions of the individuals remaining and ensure their safety.
6.1.14.2	Each year, the site develops an exercise drill plan and schedule with the local response agencies to address a release of chlorine.  Other scenarios (i.e. injuries, fire, release of other chemicals) are also exercised throughout the year and many times incorporated into a larger exercise scenario.

6.1.15	Trade Secrets
6.1.15.1	Seneca employees are provided with all information necessary to comply with the provisions of the Process Safety Management Regulation without regard to possible trade secret status.  The information is available electronically to applicable Seneca employees.  Refer to the Seneca Trade Secrets Procedure EHS 06003 located in CompliantPro for more details.

6.1.10	Contractors
6.1.10.1	BASF Seneca evaluates each contractor's safety performance and safety programs prior to pre-qualifying/selecting the contractor.  Prior to access on site, all pre-qualified contractors are vetted and tracked in Avetta.  The Contractor EHS Management and the Contractor Safety Manual EHS 01017 located in CompliantPro describes the work process for evaluating the contractor's performance prior to working at Seneca, during work and regularly thereafter.  Checklists and bid inserts are available to ensure clear understanding of BASF personnel and the contractor employer responsibilities and expectations.

6.1.11.1	The BASF Seneca facility has identified key areas of employee participation and documented them in a written Seneca Employee Participation PSM Procedure EHS 06004 located in CompliantPro.
6.1.11.2	Employees are consulted when developing, revising and executing all fourteen (14) program elements of the Process Safety Program. 

6.1.12	Hot Work Permit
6.1.12.1	Seneca has implemented a Hot Work Procedure, used in conjunction with the Work Permit Procedure that specifies criteria for issuing and approvals required for hot work operations.  A Hot Work Checklist is also utilized to verify the appropriate preparations, safeguards, and reviews are conducted and documented prior to initiating the work.  More information regarding hot work permits is provided in the Hot Work Procedure EHS 02015 located in CompliantPro.

6.1.7	Compliance Audits
6.1.7.1	BASF Seneca has established and implemented an audit work process according to Occupational Safety and Health Administration PSM regulation (29 CFR 1910.119).  PSM/RMP audits are conducted internally at least once every three years and reported findings shall be documented in an action tracking system.  The audits are to be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process and are meant to verify that the procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being followed.  Prompt and appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and documentation that deficiencies have been corrected will be documented in the action tracking system used.
6.1.7.2	At  a minimum, the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports must be retained and available for audit.

6.1.8	Management of Change
6.1.8.1	BASF Seneca has established and implemented a written work process (Change Management) to manage any changes that are not replacement-in-kind.  The procedure requires that prior to making any revisions, the proposed change is evaluated regarding; the impact of the proposed change on employee safety and health; the modifications to Operating Procedures and other PSI; the technical basis/justification of the change; the time required to implement the proposed change and the authorization requirements for the proposed change.  These evaluations and applicable approvals are documented in the Change Management database.  Action items are listed in the BASF Action Tracker system.  Refer to the Seneca Change Management Procedure EHS SOP 014 located in CompliantPro for more details.

and certified on an annual basis by the Area responsible person.  Those procedures contain critical operating processes which indicate an approach to mitigating a critical process safety event (i.e., a life-threatening injury or a serious environmental impact that can be controlled directly or indirectly in normal operation by operator action).

6.1.4	Training
6.1.4.1	A training matrix is utilized by Seneca to define required training by PMU role.  Personnel operating process units receive initial training and regular refresher training as defined in the BASF Seneca Training Procedure.  Training documents are maintained in a file in the Training Department and/or electronically.

6.1.5	Mechanical Integrity
6.1.5.1	BASF Seneca has established and implemented written procedures to maintain integrity of the process equipment.  Seneca requires documentation that inspections and tests are performed.  Seneca ensures that equipment is built and installed according to design specifications and manufacturer instructions and that all maintenance materials, spare parts, and equipment meet design specifications.  Any equipment deficiencies outside acceptable limits are addressed through the Change Management and AIMS processes.  Seneca employees involved in maintaining integrity of the process equipment are trained in an overview of the process and its hazards and all procedures pertaining to the employee's job.  For additional information regarding mechanical integrity, see the Seneca Mechanical Integrity Program TES 0001 located in CompliantPro.

Seneca PSM/RMP Program Overview
1.	PURPOSE

The purpose of this procedure is to expand on the Corporate & Site guidelines pertaining to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), Process Safety Management (PSM) and EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations and their impact on the Seneca Site.  This document also serves as the PSM/RMP Applicability Document, in conjunction with the Chlorine Distribution and Dissolution Reactors P&IDs.

The practices of an effective process safety management program that are similar to OSHA's Process Safety Management program - 29 CFR 1910.119 are followed at the BASF Seneca site in order to prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of toxic, reactive, flammable, or explosive chemicals occurrence.

2.	DEFINITIONS

2.1.	See Attachment 1 for a listing of terms and their definitions associated with PSM/RMP.

3.	RESPONSIBILTIES

3.1.	Site Leadership Team (SLT):  All SLT are directly responsible for the safety of personnel on site and must ensure employees in their organizations are trained in and comply with the provisions of this Procedure.
3.2.	The site EHS team with support from the Process Safety Expert Services (PSES) is responsible to ensure this policy meets statutory and company requirements.
3.3.	Seneca Personnel:  All BASF Seneca employees (permanent, contracted or contingent) and visitors are required to comply with all aspects of this Procedure
